translated: Commentary on the PrajÃ±ÄpradÄ«pa, Fascicle 3
Verses by Ä€rya NÄgÄrjuna, Commentary by BhÄviveka
Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master PrabhÄkaramitra of India during the Great Tang

Chapter on the Examination of Coming and Going, Chapter 2 on the Examination of Coming and Going. Furthermore, the first chapter has already explained that the essence of all dharmas is without arising, and has refuted [the opponent's] arguments, causing people to understand and believe.

Now, it is further explained that dependent arising is without coming and going, distinguishing [the correct view] from [the opponent's] view, in order to make people recognize and understand, and to refute [the opponent's] meaning.
Why does the second chapter arise?
In worldly dharmas, speech is sovereign, and one deeply gives rise to attachment to what is done.
Now, in order to pull out the arrow of attachment, one refutes one aspect of practice. This external activity is then easily refuted.
What is meant by that? The opponent says:
There should be such arising of the essence of internal sense bases.
Why is it so?
Because their objects can be distinguished and spoken of.
If there is no arising of this, then the distinction of objects cannot be spoken of.
Like the daughter of a barren woman, one cannot say that she comes or goes. If it is Devadatta or YajÃ±adatta, it is not like this.
By this analogy, the meaning of the arising of one's own and others' dharmas is established.
The treatise says:

If giving, morality, meditation, etc. are accomplished by the arising of their own-nature through much practice, or if they are understood by the world as action or abiding, then this is already accomplished and becomes an error.

Like one in concentration observing with the eye of wisdom, those giving, morality, etc., in action and non-action, their essence cannot be attained in the ultimate truth, and the distinction of their objects can be spoken of. Because the meaning of the cause is not established.
Like the cessation of action, action is also refuted in the same way.
Furthermore, if one says that I establish the cause and seed, and that discrimination is accomplished together with you, this meaning is not so.
Why is it so?
Because the cause of that accomplishment is examined and found to be without substance.
Such different views are verified and contradict the meaning of that reason.
Moreover, if in the ultimate truth there is going, then the three of already gone, not yet gone, and the place of going should be obtainable.
As a verse says:
The already gone should not be accepted.
The explanation says:
It is said that the dharma of going has already passed,
this meaning is understood by both self and others, and does not need to be established.
The verse says:
The not yet gone is also not accepted.
The explanation says:
Because of the goer.
Like the already gone, the meaning is like this.
Moreover, how is it not yet gone?
It is said that the goer has not yet begun, because that dharma has not yet gone, the able and the accomplished dharmas are both able to be accomplished.
Because of the example of the dharma substance and dharma characteristics wanting to go.
This is also how.
Moreover, why is the not yet gone also not accepted? This meaning is established.
Why is it so?
Because it has not yet gone, it is like any other person who desires to go.
Next, the disciples of the Ä€jÄ«vikas say:
What has not yet gone?
Is it like Devadatta who has not yet gone, but is going, and thus is not accepted?
Or is it like Devadatta who has gone, but is made to be not going, in order to make others understand?
The treatise says:
For what reason do you ask in this way?
The opponent says:
If your intention is to accept the previous analysis, then it confirms my meaning.
If your intention is to accept the later analysis, then it contradicts your reason.
Therefore, the previous reason is not unestablished.
Furthermore, I establish that apart from the real, there is a separate dharma of going.
Your statement that it is not so is incorrect, because apart from the real, there is going.
How is this established?
It refers to the combination of the meaning of the phrase outside of the self, and the object of Devadatta, who has the going of Devadatta.
My intention is like this, because it follows and transforms, like the combination of Devadatta, one should understand it in this way.
The treatise says:

If in the conventional truth there is going combined with Devadatta, manifesting the combination of the meaning of the sentence outside of its own nature, because of that object, it gives rise to the understanding of going and causes others to understand. In the conventional truth, it is established, and it is established as a fault.
Why is this?
There is only the difference between the edge of a place and the previous and later moments, called combination.
The name Devadatta is only a collection of activities, since it itself has no substance, how can there be a separate going that combines with it?
This is the wisdom I desire.
Furthermore, the meaning of the sentence called going combined with Devadatta, in the ultimate truth, has no analogy, therefore its substance cannot be obtained.
In this way, in the conventional truth it also contradicts reason, let alone in the ultimate truth.
These faults you cannot escape.
Next, the SautrÄntika says:
Because of desire, wind elements and the four great elements are produced, called the body aggregate. Without interval at the edge of the place, arising and ceasing before and after are called going.
If you say there is a separate external dharma of going, this is not so.
Why is it so?
Because where it arises, the goer ceases.
It is like a flame. Deluded people say it goes, but in reality it does not.
In the ultimate truth, there is also no time of going.
In the ultimate truth, you refute the goer, but this commits the fallacy of affirming what is to be established.
The treatise says:
Because you refute arising, your explanation is not established.
Why is it so?
Because the delusion of going in a flame is the same as the delusion of knowledge. The difference between the goer and going is also to be refuted.
Moreover, worldly wise people do not rejoice in your assertion.
Next, the SÄá¹ƒkhya says:
In our dharma, the increase of movement is biased, and the effect then turns to understanding, because the one who has not yet gone is said to be going.
The treatise says:
Because the understanding and so forth have already been refuted, the meaning of going is not established, this is only conceptualization.
Furthermore, those who speak of the goer, hearing the previous faults, their minds become fearful, and they jointly establish the statement:
Because going is at the time of going, there is no previous fault, this meaning is certain.
The treatise's verse says:
Apart from the gone and the not-yet-gone, the time of going is also not accepted.
The commentary says:
What does this mean?
Because the time of going cannot be attained.
If there is a time of going, is it the gone?
Or is it the not-yet-gone?
If it is half gone and half not-yet-gone, both have faults.
The opponent says:
Your statement that the time of going is also not accepted is not so.
Why is it so?
This should be accepted.
How do we know?
The appearance of raising and lowering the foot is called the time of going.
As a verse says:
Not where one has gone, nor where one has not gone, is there the going of the goer.
The commentary says:
What we want to say is that because there is a time of going, the meaning of going can be established.
Furthermore, someone says:
If there is a place to go, then one can say there is going.
Such verbal expressions have substance, because action and support are inseparable.
As for where one has gone and where one has not gone, it is not said that going is negated, this is not appropriate.
What you say about the time of going not being accepted, since the meaning is not established, where one has gone and where one has not gone are also not refuted.
The treatise states in verse:
If the goer goes at the time of going, how can this be so?
The commentary says:
As you want to say, the goer goes at the time of going.
This meaning is not established.
Why is it so?
Because it is the goer.
Because it has already been refuted that the one who has gone has gone.
Moreover, if one definitely distinguishes the goer at the time of going, is there going in that which has gone?
Is there going in that which has not gone?
Or is there going in that which is other than these two?
As it was said before, there is a fault.
Moreover, in the ultimate truth, the time of going and the goer are examined to be without substance.
What is the meaning of this?
The verse says:
Because the time of going is empty of going, the time of going does not go.
The explanation says:
It is like asking, Whose horse is this?
The answer is, It belongs to the one who has a horse.
Again, it is asked, Whose horse?
The answer is, It belongs to the one who has a stable.
In the same way, it is asked, What is the time of going?
The answer is, It is where one goes.
It is asked, Where does one go?
The answer is, At the time of going.
Both are not clear.ğŸ”½Or it is said that the time of going is understood in the conventional truth from beginningless [time].
In that ultimate truth, it is not reasonable to establish going.
Why is this?
This going activity belongs to the time of going. Apart from this, where else is there going, such that it is said that at the time of going, there is going?

Therefore, your statement that in the ultimate truth, the arising of the internal sense bases and their distinctions in objects are spoken of, and you cite Devadatta and so forth as examples, the thesis, reason, and example are all unestablished, because in the ultimate truth, they have no substance.
Or it may be said that in this way, the going activity does not belong to the time of going, and because it does not belong, it is designated as going.
Because it has substance, the reason is not unestablished.
As the verse says:
Speaking of going at the time of going.
The explanation says:
The time of going and going should be like this.
But saying there is no goer, this assertion has an error.
Therefore, the verse says:
There is no going in the time of going.
The explanation says:
If in the time of going there is no goer, then it cannot be said to be the time of going.
When going, there is no goer, the world does not accept it.
Therefore, the going action belongs to the time of going, and the meaning of their combination is definitely so.
Your statement that there is no going but a separate goer is not reasonable, because it has faults.
If you want to avoid the previous faults and insist that going and the time of going combine and proceed like this, this is not reasonable.
As a verse says:
Going combines with the time of going, the goer is only conceptual.
The commentary says:
In the ultimate truth, going, combining, etc. are all unobtainable, but are only conceptual.
If it is definitely like this, what faults are incurred?
A verse says:
If going is in the time of going, and also in this proceeding,
Then it falls into the fault of two goings, this meaning is not so.
The commentary says:
This means that in the conventional truth, the meaning is not so.
Moreover, a verse says:
If there were two dharmas of going, then there would be two goers.
The commentary says:
For what reason is this kind of negation made?
If there were two dharmas, then there would be two goers.
The verse says:
Apart from the goer, there is going, this is not reasonable.
The commentary says:
For this reason, this should not be so.
Because the previous faults should be purified.
What is this again?
In this way, in the conventional truth, observing that one going, the goer's going is accomplished.

In the ultimate truth, it is the opposite. In this way, their distinctions, verbal expressions, and analogies, etc., are examined to be without substance, therefore the internal sense bases do not arise, there is no coming or going, and dependent arising is accomplished.
Next, the Vaiseá¹£ika says:
The meaning established by me does not have the previous faults.
Why is this?
Because there is only one action, the self-nature of going.
When one moves there, it is called going.
The one who performs that movement is called the goer.
Therefore, your statement that there are two goers and two acts of going is not correct.
The treatise states:
In the ultimate truth, going is refuted, so time has no substance.
Since time has no substance, going is also not established.
In the conventional truth, the uninterrupted continuation of movement at the limit of a location is called the goer.
Analyzing the time of going, it truly has no self-nature, this is not appropriate.
Again, someone says:
Going definitely exists, one should understand it in this way.
What does this mean?
Because that which is based on it exists.
If that which is based on it does not exist, it also does not exist.
Like the child of a barren woman, or the action of falling over, etc.
What is the characteristic of going based on the goer?
It refers to Devadatta.
Therefore, if that which is based on it exists, then going exists, because the cause is established.
In this way, the arising and going and not yet gone, etc. of the internal sense bases are all established.
The treatise states in verse:
Apart from the goer, there is no going.
The commentary explains:
You say that the goer is the basis of going, and because this basis exists, it is the cause of going. This is not reasonable.
Why is it so?
If the cause is not yet mentioned, going is not established.
You cannot escape this fault.
As stated in the verse:
Apart from the goer, there is no going. This is unreasonable.
The commentary explains:
If apart from the goer, going is not established.
The meaning of this sentence has already been analyzed.
Therefore, the verse states:
If there is no going, where is the goer?
The commentary explains:
The reason for the goer is that it is without substance. This is the meaning.
What does the word where mean?
It means that if there is no goer, the meaning of the statement can be established.
As it has been extensively explained before, the goer has no substance.
Thus, the basis is a fallacy of non-establishment of the reason,
and it contradicts the meaning.
Again, someone says:
Because going is perceptible, there is no fault in the previous assertion.
You should listen carefully, I definitely establish that there is such going.
What does this mean?
If there is a combination here, it can be pointed out.
If there is no combination here, it cannot be pointed out.
Just as a rabbit does not have horns, it cannot be pointed out and said to have horns.
Now there is going and a combination that can be pointed out, saying that Devadatta goes.
Because there is going, my thesis is established.
The treatise states:
If you definitely think that there is going of Devadatta that can be pointed out, do you wish to show that in the ultimate truth there is a goer?
Or that there is no goer?
As stated in the verse:
The goer does not go.
The explanation says:
Now this meaning should be established through skillful explanation.
Namely, in the ultimate truth, the goer does not go.
Why is it so?
Because it is an action, like the one who is staying.
Therefore, one should understand that the goer does not go.
Someone else says:
I now establish that the non-goer goes.
Using this skillful means, I cannot refute you.
The treatise says:
Just as in the conventional truth, the goer is said to go in conjunction with going, the meaning of the goer going has already been refuted. Now how can you say that the non-goer goes?
As a verse says:
The non-goer does not go.
The explanation says:
The non-goer does not go because he lacks going. The meaning is like this.
Furthermore, if the non-goer, how can he be going?
If at some time he is going, how can he be called the non-goer?
This is self-contradictory.
Furthermore, the provisional explanation is as follows: in the ultimate truth, that which has not yet gone is not called going.
Why is this?
Because going is empty, just like that which is different.
The previously refuted statements should be made for the masters of one's own school and the husk-eating non-Buddhists, etc.
Next, the SÄá¹ƒkhya says:
As you say, that which has not yet gone is called not going.
The meaning you establish accomplishes what I have already established.
The treatise states:
What is called that which has not yet gone?
The opponent says:
Because going is not yet clear, it is called that which has not yet gone;
If going is already clear, it is called the goer.
The treatise states:
The clarity you speak of has faults, as was previously refuted.
Furthermore, if you say that which has not yet performed going is called that which has not yet gone, this is not so.
Why is this?
Because you yourself refute it.
It means that before the goer has gone, going has its own substance. Your meaning is like this.
Moreover, you say that because of the non-goer, the goer does not exist.
This intention is not so.
Why is it so?
Because you establish your own meaning and still refute it yourself.
It means that before going is made, the substance of the goer cannot be attained.
Furthermore, someone says:ğŸ”½Because there is a different category, it is called the goer;
Because there is a different category, it is called the non-goer.
By this meaning being established, there is no such fault above.
The treatise says:
You say that apart from the goer and the non-goer, there is a third category that combines with them. This meaning is not so.
Why is it so?
As a verse says:
Apart from going and not going, there is no third goer.
The commentary says:
What does this clarify?
That is, apart from the goer and the nongoer, there is no third, because this is the goer and the nongoer.
There is such a person, difficult to make others understand.
Moreover, the goer and the nongoer have already been refuted earlier.
You say that because there is a different category, it is called the goer, and because there is a different category, it is called the nongoer. This meaning is not established.
If you say that because the goer has activity, this activity is not universal, and the meaning of your reason is not established, because it is without activity, this is not so.
Why is it so?
You say that the goer is combined with going, and in this way going is what I refute.
For example, like the activity that produces sound, it is impermanent.
Although activity is not universal, because of activity, impermanence is established.
In this way, the goer is combined with going, and I refute this, so the reason is not established.
If there is an establishment of the meaning of not yet gone, one should also answer with this reason of not yet gone.
If one says there is a goer, but no one who goes or stays,
the proposition of a stayer, the analogy is without substance, and the established dharma is incomplete in one part, this is not so.
Why is it so?
The established part is understood by both parties.
I cite a stayer as an analogy, so what is wrong with that?
In this way, saying one person is a goer, this meaning is not so.

As previously stated, the reason is because there is going combined, therefore it can be indicated. Using this as a reason, the reason is not established, and the analogy is also without substance, because the established dharma is complete, and it contradicts the meaning of the reason.
The opponent says:
The world's eyes see that goer going, and after seeing, they speak.
Although there is hearing and so forth, it is not as good as seeing with the eyes.
For this reason, the reasons and so forth are not established.
The treatise says:
They see this way, and in the conventional truth, wisdom takes this as real.
In the ultimate truth, if one observes with proper reasoning, what is called seeing?
If one takes what is seen in the conventional truth as the ultimate truth, that cannot be trusted.
How can this be known?
As a verse says:
If one says the goer goes, how can this meaning be established?
The commentary says:
The meaning of the goer going is not established.
It is like a person who claims to be brave, but when facing the battlefield, they retreat in fear.
If this bravery is established, your meaning would be proven.
How is it not established?
As a verse says:
Because the goer has no going, the meaning is not established in this way.
The commentary says:
Just as going has no substance, as I have already explained, in order to make others understand.
Where is it explained?
As a verse above says, because the one who has gone does not go, and that the arising of going has already been refuted.
The one who has gone and the one who has not gone - this is the statement of the thesis, causing others to understand.
How does it cause understanding?
As stated in the above verse, if it is said that the goer goes.
What does this mean?
It is accomplished equally as previously analyzed.
Thus, in the ultimate truth, there is no going and no goer. Because going is unreal, it is merely falsely posited that the goer is called going.
The disputant establishes the thesis in this way, incurring this fault.
What is the fault?
The verse states:
Since the goer's going is empty, how can there be the going of the goer?
The commentary states:
If it is said that going is accomplished, the goer is united with that going. This is not so.
Why is it so?
If you wish to avoid the previous fault, in the ultimate truth, establishing one going united with the goer, that is called going. This assertion then falls into the fault of two goings.
As stated in the verse:
If the goer is united with going, then there is the fault of two goings.
Why is this so?
The verse says:
One is the goer who has gone, the other is the goer who goes.
The explanation says:
For this reason, there is a separate fault.
Namely, falling into two goers. How is this again?
The verse says:
Apart from the goer, there is going, this is not so.
The explanation says:
If the basis does not exist, the dependent does not exist. The meaning is like this. Necessarily, there is no going.
Because there is a goer, and there are two goings.
Because there are two goers, there should be going, and it is called a goer.
Moreover, because going and the goer are one, it is established in the conventional truth, not in the ultimate truth.
Because in the ultimate truth, the analogy is non-existent, as they have said, the reasoning is not established.
The opponent says:
Going definitely exists.
Why is this?
Because there is a beginning of movement.
If there were no objects in the world, there would be no initial arising, like a sky flower.
Because there are objects in the world, the turning away from that place is called the beginning, and is said to be the aspect of movement. Therefore there is going.
The treatise states:
It is like dyeing a chicken - although the color changes later, the chicken remains the same.
You are also like this - although the words are different from before, the meaning is no different.
As asked before, I now ask you again:ğŸ”½Is that which has already gone called the beginning?
Is that which has not yet gone called the beginning?
Is that which is going called the beginning?
All three are unreasonable.
As stated in the verse:
There is no beginning in that which has gone, nor is there a beginning in that which has not yet gone.
There is no beginning in the moment of going - where can there be a beginning?
The commentary states:
There is no beginning in that which has gone means that the function of going has already ceased there.
One who has not yet gone also does not initiate going, because one who has not yet gone does not have going.

One who is in the process of going also does not initiate going, because one who has already gone and one who has not yet gone both lack the meaning of going. How can it be said that in the process of going there is going?
In this way, these three kinds are all without an initial initiation. Therefore, the verse says, Where can there be an initiation?
For this reason, your reason is not established, and your thesis is also destroyed.

In this way, it is explained that one who has already gone, one who has not yet gone, and one in the process of going do not have an initial initiation, causing people to understand and believe. The meaning of the words is like this.
How is it examined?

It is said that one who has already gone does not have an initial initiation, because he is a goer.ğŸ”½Like one who has already gone, one who has not yet gone also does not have an initiation, because he has not yet gone.
Like one who desires to go, one in the process of going does not have an initiation, because he is a goer, like one who has already gone and one who has not yet gone.
In this way, the initial arising has no substance, and the meaning of cause is not established, because it is claimed to be a cause with faults.
The opponent says:

I have a different view, namely, because there is the expression going, by this method, going has its own substance, because of the distinction of its own state, and also because it is the cause for the arising of the distinct language of the compound meaning.

If this does not exist, then the cause for the arising of the distinct language of the compound meaning in its own state would not exist, just like a congenitally blind person, whose eye consciousness is ultimately non-existent due to the lack of a compound. One cannot say that the congenitally blind person has already seen, is seeing, or will see.

Now, there is the compound meaning of the dharma of going and its own state, and the cause for the arising of the distinct language. Therefore, it can be said that when that activity ceases, it is called already gone, when the dharma of going is in the process of arising, it is called going, and when the activity of going has not yet begun, it is called not yet gone.
Therefore, I say that because the cause has power, the dharma of going is not empty.
The intended meaning is accomplished, without the previous fault.
The treatise states:
If there is a dharma of going that can be said to be the time of going, then the already gone and not yet gone would be so.
That going is without substance has been extensively explained before.
You again grasp at existence, which will now be refuted.
As a verse says:
Before the departure there is no time of going, and there is also no already gone,
That initial arising of going is empty, where does the not yet gone depart from?
The commentary states:
The previous non-departure is not combined with that, because going does not arise. The meaning of the verse is like this.
First explaining the emptiness of going, causing others to understand, because it refutes the established meaning of the opponent.
Furthermore, where does the not yet gone depart from? This clarifies that because going is non-existent,
In this way, in the ultimate truth, discrimination does not arise.
What does this mean?
A verse says:
There is no already gone or not yet gone, and also no time of going;
In the dharma of non-going, why falsely discriminate?
The explanation says:
False discrimination is like a person with cataracts seeing hairs, mosquitoes, flies, etc. in empty space, all of which are without substance.
As a verse says:
Thus at all times, never seeing an initial arising,
To say there is going, etc., the faults are then very many.
The explanation says:
It is like NÄrÄyaá¹‡a pursuing that exhausted KumbhÄá¹‡á¸a-Asura King, he is also like this, the faults of going, etc. always follow you.
Furthermore, someone says:
In the ultimate truth, the dharma of going exists.
Why is it so?
Because of mutual contradiction.
That is to say, contradiction can be obtained everywhere in mutual dependence.
For example, like light and darkness, thus the contradiction with abiding can obtain going, to say there is no going is not reasonable.
The treatise states:
The one who establishes this meaning should also be asked, whom do you intend to make abide?ğŸ”½Is it the one who has gone?
Or is it the one who has not yet gone?
If the one who has gone abides, the meaning is not so.
As a verse says:
The one who has gone does not abide.
The commentary says:
This means that in the ultimate truth, the establishment of the one who has gone abiding cannot be attained.
Why is it so?
Because the one who has gone is in motion, like Devadatta who has not yet stopped moving.
If it is said that the one who has not yet gone abides, this is also not so.
As a verse says:
The one who has not yet gone does not abide.
The commentary says:
Because that one who has not yet gone has no going, in the conventional truth, his going ceases, and he is called abiding.
This meaning is not established because going has no substance.
Moreover, those who are upheld by evil views and are controlled by wrong attachments make such statements, wishing to attain different abodes.
As a verse says:
Apart from the gone and the not-yet-gone, what is the third that abides?
The explanation is:
Without a single abiding, it is said to be abiding. This meaning is possible, and the intention of the verse is like this.
Moreover, a verse says:
If the goer were to abide, how could this meaning be established?
Because the goer and going are empty, going and abiding cannot be obtained.
The explanation is:
Because going and abiding are mutually exclusive and cannot occur simultaneously, the intention of the verse is like this.
As for the emptiness of going, it causes people to understand that the goer and abiding have no essence that can be shown.
An outsider says:
Just as a potter, in the three periods of time, is able to create without losing it.
In the same way, although the goer does not go, he is still called a goer.
Because this meaning is established, there is no fault.
The treatise says:
You accept the provisional dharma, but what was previously established in the ultimate truth is now all destroyed.
For this reason, the previously stated reasons and analogies have faults.
Moreover, there is another principle that reveals their faults.
What is the meaning of the abiding that you establish?ğŸ”½Is it that the goer who has already gone rests and is called abiding?
Or is it that the goer who has not yet gone or is going rests and is called abiding?
All three are unreasonable.
Why is it so?
The verse states:
When going, there is no abiding.
The explanation states:
If it is said that the union of going and the goer is called abiding, this meaning is unreasonable.
The opponent says:
The meaning of what I previously stated, that the already gone is called abiding, is established and can be trusted as a valid cognition.
The treatise verse states:
Because there is no already gone.
The explanation states:
The meaning of the already gone abiding is unreasonable.
Why is it so?
The one who has already gone is gone, because the going has already ceased, and the one who is staying has nothing to remove.
If your idea is that the one who has not yet gone is called staying, this is also not so.
Why is it so?
Because it is not reasonable for the one who has not yet gone to rest.
For this reason, the one who has not yet gone is also not called staying. In this way, the meaning of the reason is not established, and the inference also has no substance.
What does this mean?
Light and darkness, etc., cannot be established in the ultimate truth, because they are contradictory, and also because they contradict your established meaning.
Again, someone says:
I establish the meaning of staying because of contradiction, because there is an initial arising;
and because that which can be removed has a substance that arises.
This meaning is not so, because it has faults.
As a verse says:
The faults of arising, making, and cessation are the same as those explained in going.
The commentary says:
The one who goes, the one who has not yet gone, and going apart from these two are all unreasonable.
And going where one has already gone, where one has not yet gone, and at the time of going, the initial arising of going is also unreasonable.
In this way, going where one has already gone, where one has not yet gone, at the time of going, and the cessation of going are all unestablished.
In this way, the one who abides, the one who has not yet abided, and abiding apart from these two are all unreasonable.
Because abiding is unreasonable, abiding where one has already abided, where one has not yet abided, at the time of abiding, and the initial arising of abiding cannot be obtained.

Because the initial arising is nonexistent, the meanings of abiding where one has already abided, where one has not yet abided, at the time of abiding, and the cessation of abiding are all unestablished.
As explained in detail above.
Because the text is verbose, it is now briefly shown.
What is the meaning of this?
The one who abides does not abide.
Why is it so?
Because going is empty.
Like the one who has already abided, the one who has not yet completed abiding, the one who has long abided, and the initial arising of abiding are nonexistent.
Why is it so?
Because they have already abided, like one who has already abided for a long time.
Moreover, one who has already abided has no abiding to remove.
Why is this?
Because going has no substance, like one who has not yet passed beyond abiding.
As in the case of already abiding, the three statements are displayed. The same is true for not yet abiding and the time of abiding. The previous methods should be used to examine and refute them.
In this way, the meaning of abiding is not established because of faults.
The opponent says:
Your statement that there is no going and no goer is not correct.
Why is this?
Because it destroys worldly dharmas.
Worldly people all say, Devadatta goes, or YajÃ±adatta goes.
Your statement is not so, and contradicts the world.
Just as the world all knows that the moon is the moon, and there are people who say it is a rabbit and not the moon, you are also like this.
The treatise says:
What is the meaning of the reason you establish?
Is it contradictory to what is understood in the world?
Is it contradictory to your own treatise's understanding?
If so, what is the fault?
If it contradicts worldly understanding, the reason is not established.
Why is it so?
Because going and the goer cannot be found in the ultimate truth.
In this way, going and the goer as understood in the world, I do not deny them in the conventional truth.
If it contradicts your own treatise's understanding, does it refute such an intention?
If you make this statement, you do not understand the meaning.
You should say that your acceptance is refuted, and you incur this fault.
This is not so.
Why is it so?
I also do not adhere to my own treatise's understanding.
Because in the ultimate truth, both going and the goer are not accepted as having their own nature, as has already been refuted.
Moreover, if in the ultimate truth, going and the goer definitely exist, either as the same or different, they should be findable upon seeking.
Thus, upon examination, both are unreasonable.
As a verse says:ğŸ”½The dharma of going is the goer, thus it is unreasonable;
The dharma of going is different from the goer, this meaning is also unreasonable.
How are these two meanings unreasonable?
A verse says:
If it is said that the dharma of going is precisely the goer,
The doer and the action would then have the fault of being one entity.
The explanation says:
The meaning of such a statement has the fault of being upside down.
Just as sound is permanent, a pot is also permanent, because it is made.
This meaning is not established.
Why is it so?
If a pot is made, it is not called permanent.
For this reason, sound is impermanent, because it is made, just like that pot.
This statement can be trusted.
Thus, in the ultimate truth, going and the goer, these two are not one.
Why is it so?
Because of the agent and action, like that which cuts and that which is cut.
These two appearances are also not different.
Why is this?
Because going and the goer are mutually empty, like other things.
Someone may object:
If going and the goer are mutually empty, emptiness has no different characteristics and its essence cannot be apprehended.
The example you cite of that which cuts and that which is cut is not established.
The treatise states:
You speak unskillfully, because you only refute one.
The difference in characteristics between the two is fully understood in the world.
Thus that which cuts and that which is cut are mutually empty, and this meaning is established.
Like the two, that which perceives and that which is perceived, are mutually empty.
In the conventional truth, the two characteristics are different, so they are used as an example, and the example is not unestablished.
If it is said that in the ultimate truth, the two essences of that which cuts and that which is cut are not different,
why is this?
Because of their quantity, it is like the body that is cut.
Their establishment of oneness is not reasonable.
Why is it so?
Because the body that is cut is not different, it is not established.
Why is it not established?
Because in the ultimate truth, the two extremes of oneness and difference are not accepted.
In the conventional truth, the object and subject are each different, but to say they are one contradicts worldly understanding.
Moreover, if your intention is to say that I refute the goer and going not being the same, and therefore accept the extreme of difference, this is also unreasonable.
As it was said before, in the ultimate truth, I do not accept either extreme of oneness or difference, so there is no fault of accepting difference.
Furthermore, someone says:

As I establish the thesis, there is no previous fault, because from beginningless time, the seeds of conceptual proliferation of names and expressions serve as the cause, and the various effects arise through the power of dependent origination, and the power of false imagination.
This view wants to make the departing and the one who departs definitely different. In order to refute that, it says in the verse:
If you say that the dharma of departing is definitely different from the one who departs,
the commentary says:
In conventional discrimination, there is no refutation.
If one truly investigates, the meaning is not so.
How is it not so?
As the verse says:
Apart from departing, there is one who departs; apart from one who departs, there is departing.
The commentary says:
How can these two exist separately?

Because they are different, like a pot, clothes, and so forth.ğŸ”½What they say is different, but they also do not want to make one who departs apart from departing, and departing apart from one who departs, because the supported and the supporter are observed to exist.

As for the skillful explanation, in the ultimate truth they do not want to make departing and one who departs have distinctions, because the arising of distinguished language has opposition, like the self-nature of departing.
In this way, in the ultimate truth, we do not wish to distinguish a separate act of going apart from the goer.
Why is this?
Because the arising of a distinct statement involves dependence, like the self-nature of the goer.
The opponent says:
The other school turns back and does not allow others to understand, you incur this fault.
The treatise says:
The other school is without substance, the meaning of turning back is established.
The opponent says:
The world itself has the supported and the supporter, not necessarily in union.
Your statement of dependence, this reason's meaning is not established.
Why is this?
Because in the examined object, one part is not universal.
The treatise says:
Those various things and so forth also have this and that, because the observation of characteristics is different, dependence is without fault, the reason is not unestablished.
Your statement of the examined object, in the end, is establishing difference.
Difference is previously refuted, therefore non-difference is established.
The other school is without substance, also not the two extremes.
The worldly understanding is also not destroyed.
How is it not destroyed?
In this treatise, the true observation of the proper combination of the supported and the support is not the observed object of uncontaminated wisdom, as explained above.
Next, some people say:
The goer is different from going, because it can be indicated.
For example, Devadatta and his horse, because the two characteristics of the supported and the support are different.
The treatise says:
You speak unskillfully, because the meaning of the goer's own nature is not established.
Because Devadatta and the horse are different, this meaning is not established, because in the ultimate truth the analogy has no substance.
If there is wrong wisdom discriminating the characteristics of various causes and distinctions, it is also answered with this meaning.
Next, the VaiÅ›eá¹£ikas say:
The wise and intelligent understand it like this, namely, the sound of the goer, this external to its own nature, has going, with the meaning of the phrase properly combined.
Like Devadatta, who is the object of knowledge, because of turning and not turning.
Like saying blue-robed, the rest are not included.
If it were not so, the sound of the goer should not have the difference of turning and not turning, like being.
The treatise says:
Your establishment of this difference as a logical reason is not correct.
Why is it so?

Because the supported and the supporter are not substantially existent, and the combination of going and the goer has already been refuted before, the logical reason is also not established. How do we know?
It is because many people with the same name are not combined with the meaning of their own bodies.
Whether two, three, or even innumerable Devadattas, by this logical reason, we know that the sound of turning and not turning is not one-sided.
The opponent says:
Because there is distinction, although they have the same name, only the sound of the black long Devadatta going applies to him, not to the others.
For this reason, my argument is established, not unilaterally so.
The treatise states:
As you say, in the ultimate truth, because AjÄtaÅ›atru has no essence, the reason is not established.
The example of a blue robe and the object are both unobtainable in the ultimate truth.
If someone says that going is different from the goer, because there is a difference in cognition,
such a proof is refuted by the previous reason and example.

Furthermore, if you say that I establish one to negate difference, and establish difference to negate one, and ultimately do not depart from difference, so negating difference is not established, this is not so.
Why is it so?
Because both one and difference are negated, as already explained.
Using this power of reasoning to refute attachment to the two extremes, how can the cognition of those objects arise?
The wise have already understood, so I have no fault.
Therefore, your statement that I refute the goer and going are not different, and establish the thesis that the receiver is not different, I have no such fault.
Moreover, if you carefully examine and accept my previous statement, the analogy of the goer's own body being not different, the thesis is not established.
As for the claim that the analogy is without substance and faults me, this is not so.
Why is it so?

Apart from the substance of the goer, there is no other dharma, and due to the absence of other dharmas, the substance of the goer is established. Since the substance is established, the analogy is without fault.
Thus, the VaiÅ›eá¹£ika people and those who consume husks and so forth, concealing their faults, wish to destroy the correct principle, as previously stated, the proofs are all unestablished.
Again, someone says:
You previously refuted going, now you abandon it and discuss something else, whether one or different, going and the goer are both unestablished, this is not a good explanation. This is not so.
As a verse says:
The goer and going are either one or different, therefore they are established.
The explanation is:
The goer and going are either one or different.
Because of the existence of those two, can they be grasped?
If one explains by means of skillful means, either one or different, then it is as the verse says:
Those two have no establishment, how can there be going?
The explanation is:
Because of not wishing to abandon what has already been refuted, going.
By means of this meaning, the same kind of discrimination is also refuted in this way. Because in the conventional truth those two exist.
One should know that according to your idea, if in the ultimate truth going of the goer is established as either one or different,
This is not the case. The essence of one or different does not exist, but grasping it as existent, causing others to understand, this meaning is not so.
Or there may be a person who is proud of their intelligence and makes such a statement:
You say that in the ultimate truth there is no going of the goer, because it is an action and movement, like other things.
Such abiding is non-abiding, because it is an action and movement, like Devadatta.
As for the past that has not yet passed, what do these two previous examples illustrate?ğŸ”½Is the action and agent of movement external, or is this action not an action?
Or is the action and agent of movement bodily, or is this action not an action?
If it is said that external action is not action, then the analogy is not established, because that is done by a different agent.
If it is said that bodily action is not action, then it contradicts the meaning, because the speaker speaks and the cutter cuts.
The going of the body is also like this. Since the body is already in motion, how can it be said to be not an action?
Thus the previously stated examples are not established, because they have faults.
The treatise states:
The different agent does not perform the action of going. For this reason, the analogy of the agent, etc. is established.
The fault that was stated is now back on you.
Since the analogy is established, it also does not contradict the meaning.
How is it not contradictory?
As a verse says:
The goer goes by the action of going, but that going does not go.
The commentary says:
That going does not go means that in the ultimate truth, that going is not done.
Why is it so?
Because there is no difference, just like the essence of going itself.
This means that the one who speaks of no difference is refuted by their own reasoning, and also because it refutes what is commonly understood in the world.
Why is it so?
As a verse says:
Just as one sees a person going to a village, etc.
The commentary says:
The world understands that apart from the essence of that person, there are separate villages, etc.
Moreover, the goer goes by the action of going, but that going does not go.
What does this mean?
For this reason, as a verse says:
Since there is no action of going prior to the goer, the goer does not go.
The commentary says:
Just as the self of the one who abides is the cause of going and performs going, but there is no goer.

Although there is no goer, in conventional truth, the desire to go is the cause, next arises effort, the wind element becomes independent, in the uninterrupted space between places, the collection of activities arises, with differences in time, each moment different from the previous.
Because of this arising, it is called the goer.

In conventional truth, we do not really want to make the agent the cause of the agent, therefore the verse says, Just as one sees a person going to a village, etc., it is not by making the self the cause of the self.
In this way, the various schools use going to prove the goer, but that going does not go, this meaning should be understood.
Next, the SÄá¹ƒkhya says:
Due to the aggregation of earth, etc., it is separately called the body, and because those objects increase, it is called going.
In this way, the effect of going relies on the aggregated cause, and the combination of going and person is called the goer.
This assertion is not correct.
Why is it so?
Because when not yet gone, there is no goer.
If when not yet gone it is called a goer, then a dweller would also be called a goer, but this is not so in reality.
If it is said that the already gone goer is the cause of going, this is also not correct.
Why is it so?
As the previous verse says, it is seen that there is a person going to that village, etc.
What does this mean?
In this way, one should understand that going cannot be made by going.
An outsider says:
Because of the production of production, it is said to be the production of sprouts, just like a wise person produces wisdom by himself.
This assertion is not correct, but is merely false discrimination.
Because when the sprout has not yet been produced, production has nothing to do, and to say that production produces is not correct.
In this way, the self-body of the goer goes, the speaker speaks by himself, and the cutter cuts by himself, all of these are not correct.
Why is it so?
Because it is illogical for something to act on itself.

Due to the intention as the cause, next arises the cause of effort and action, which produces the collection of syllables, words, and sounds called speech. But to grasp that there is a separate substance of speech is illogical.
Thus, it is not the case that speech precedes and is called the speaker.
Next, the VaiÅ›eá¹£ika says:
As stated before, from going one knows the goer, but that going does not go.
Although you have already refuted this, the meaning is still illogical.
Why is this?
Because apart from the goer there is a separate dharma of going. For this reason there is no previous fault.
What is the separate meaning?
It refers to the awareness of reality and the awareness of action.
These two are not the same because their objects are different.
It is like the difference between the awareness of an ox and the awareness of a buffalo.
If they were not different, then the objects of those two would have no distinction, just like the awareness of an ox itself.
The treatise states:
Because of the going of the goer, that going does not go. This fault is as explained before.
Now, we refute that difference, as a verse says:
Because of the going of the goer, the different going also does not go.
The commentary says:
That which is established as different causes others to understand, because the proof lacks substance.
As a verse says:
This thing and that thing, having difference is not established.
The commentary says:
In the ultimate truth, the nature of dharmas is like this, therefore our analogy is established.
Furthermore, because of the going of the goer, the different going also does not go.
What is the meaning of this?
A verse says:
Because the goer is one, it is not reasonable for going to have two.
The commentary says:
Why is it not reasonable?
Because the proof is known.
In the ultimate truth, apart from the substance of the goer, there is no different going that goes.
Why is this?
Because it does not combine with two goings, like a dweller.
Next, the one who eats the husk says:
According to my established principle, there is only one going. Going combined with the goer is called the goer.
Because of this difference, it can be the cause of going, because it makes that going.
It is like when someone says:
That Devadatta goes.
And it is like when the lamp is the cause of light, it is called the light of the lamp.
As you said before, because the goer is one, it is not reasonable for going to be two. This is not so.
The treatise says:
You are not speaking well.
As the previously stated causes and powers, in the ultimate truth, going and not yet arising have all been refuted.
Furthermore, the goer is not the cause of the combination of going, because the arising of the cognition of sound has a separate cause, like that karma.
By this verification, one knows that your statement that going combines with the goer is merely false speech.
Why is it so?
If a person is not yet united with going, then he is not a goer, just like a dweller.
To say that he is united with the goer, this is not reasonable.
Moreover, if one examines with right wisdom, going and the goer cannot be apprehended.
As a verse says:
With real going, without real going, and with both real and unreal going,
In this way, the goer does not use the three goings.
The explanation is:
The goer with real going is called one with going because he is united with going.
What does this mean?
If there is a real goer, he does not use the three goings.
That is to say, the real goer does not go, the unreal goer does not go, and the goer with both real and unreal does not go, because he is an agent of motion, like other things.
If there is no real goer, there are also no three goings, because going is empty, like a dweller.
The goer with both real and unreal going is refuted by the same examination as before.
Just as the goer is refuted, so too is the act of going.
The establishment of the thesis, the presentation of the reason, and the analogy should be understood in this way.
Because, by observing in accordance with reasoning and scripture, going in all three times is not established.
As a verse says:
Therefore going has no nature, and the goer is also so.
The time of going and all dharmas are all nonexistent.
The commentary says:
Just as the previously established argument refutes the act of going and the goer, so too should the other produced dharmas be refuted by analogy.
In this chapter, the explanation that going has no intrinsic nature is in order to make one understand the meaning of dependent arising without coming or going, and thus it is accomplished.
As the Sutra of Inexhaustible Wisdom says:
That which has no coming and no going is called the holy coming and going.
And as the Diamond PrajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ SÅ«tra says:
Good sons!
The TathÄgata is one who has come from nowhere and goes nowhere, and for that reason is called the TathÄgata.
It is also as the Aniruddha-nirdeÅ›a-sÅ«tra says:
Coming and going are without reality, all dharmas are like empty space.
It is also as the PrajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ-sÅ«tra says:
Those particles of dust, etc., also come from nowhere and go nowhere, because their coming and going cannot be seen.
It is also as the Buddha told the bodhisattva ParamÄÅ›va:
Good man!
Because the coming and going of material dharmas cannot be seen, feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness are also like this.
The coming and going of the five aggregates that cannot be seen is called prajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ.
Such sÅ«tras should be extensively quoted here.
The chapter on the observation of coming and going is finished.
Commentary on the PrajÃ±ÄpradÄ«pa, fascicle 3
